Apple, â€œThe Digital Markets Actâ€™s Impacts on EU Usersâ€:

The DMA requires Apple to make certain features work on non-Apple products and apps before we can share them with our users. Unfortunately, that requires a lot of engineering work, and itâ€™s caused us to delay some new features in the EU:

  • iPhone Mirroring lets our users see and interact with their iPhone from their Mac, so they can seamlessly check their notifications, or drag and drop photos between devices. Our teams still have not found a secure way to bring this feature to non-Apple devices without putting all the data on a userâ€™s iPhone at risk. And as a result, we have not been able to bring the feature to the EU. [...]

Weâ€™ve suggested changes to these features that would protect our usersâ€™ data, but so far, the European Commission has rejected our proposals. And according to the European Commission, under the DMA, itâ€™s illegal for us to share these features with Apple users until we bring them to other companiesâ€™ products. If we shared them any sooner, weâ€™d be fined and potentially forced to stop shipping our products in the EU.

Live Translation with AirPods and iPhone Mirroring are both amazing features. And EU users are missing out on them. I think Apple structured this piece exactly right, by emphasizing first that the most direct effect of the DMA is that EU users are getting great features lateâ€‰â€”â€‰or never. And that list of features is only going to grow over time.

Under the section â€œIs the DMA Achieving Its Goals?â€:

Regulators claimed the DMA would promote competition and give European consumers more choices. But the law is not living up to those promises. In fact, itâ€™s having some of the opposite effects:

  • Fewer choices: When features are delayed or unavailable, EU users donâ€™t get the same options as users in the rest of the world. They lose the choice to use Appleâ€™s latest technologies, and their devices fall further behind.

  • Less differentiation: By forcing Apple to build features and technologies for non-Apple products, the DMA is making the options available to European consumers more similar. For instance, the changes to app marketplaces are making iOS look more like Androidâ€‰â€”â€‰and that reduces choice.

entry.content:
MacOS has shipped with a collection of â€œutilityâ€ apps since the prehistoric era of classic Mac OS. A good rule of thumb for what makes an app a â€œutilityâ€ is that itâ€™s a tool for doing something to or about your computer. Ever since Mac OS X 10.0, most of these apps have been neatly filed away in /Applications/Utilities/. Othersâ€‰â€”â€‰some because theyâ€™re obscure (e.g. Ticket Viewer), some because theyâ€™re effectively deprecated (e.g. DVD Player, whose copyright date in MacOS 15 Sequoia is 2019), and some because they present themselves, when launched, not as apps but as system-level features (e.g. About This Mac)â€‰â€”â€‰are tucked away in /System/Library/CoreServices/ or /System/Library/CoreServices/Applications/.

Basic Apple Guy posted a screenshot to Mastodon comparing the current MacOS 15 icons for four of these utilities (Disk Utility, Expansion Slot Utility, Wireless Diagnostics, and AppleScript Utility) to their new icons in MacOS 26 Tahoe, beta 7 (click to enlarge for detail):

I donâ€™t think the old icons for these apps from MacOS 15 were particularly goodâ€‰â€”â€‰Apple has mostly lost its â€œicons look coolâ€ game. But the new ones in MacOS 26 Tahoe are objectively terrible. The only one of this bunch thatâ€™s maybe sort of OK is Wireless Diagnostics. They all look like placeholder icons made by a developer who would be the first to admit that theyâ€™re not an artist. Disk Utility, which is an important app, doesnâ€™t even look like it involves a disk.

These new icons all use the same â€œwrenchâ€ motif, which is a lazy, limiting concept to start with. Tahoe, at the system level, enforces a squircle shape on all application icons. Apps that havenâ€™t been updated with Tahoe-compliant everything-fits-in-a-squircle icons are put in â€œsquircle jailâ€â€‰â€”â€‰their non-Tahoe-compliant icons are shrunk and placed atop a drab gray Tahoe squircle background, to force them into squircle compliance. But these Apple utility apps have an entire sub-motifâ€‰â€”â€‰inside their base squircle shape is a large wrench fitted against a bolt. Only inside the boltâ€‰â€”â€‰which is inside the wrenchâ€™s jaws, which wrench is inside the squircleâ€‰â€”â€‰goes the part of the icon that identifies the app itself. So maybe like 10 percent of the area of the icon is the area where the app can show something that identifies its purpose.

So the entire concept for these icons sucks. But the conceptual execution sucks too. The wrench is incredibly stupid-looking. Whoever drew it has obviously never used an open-end wrench because the jaws on the wrench head are way too thin. Theyâ€™d break off under any significant torque. Just look at a real-life wrench, or just look at the wrench heads in the older MacOS icons (or Appleâ€™s ğŸ”§ emoji, for that matter).

Individually the icons mostly suck too:

  • Disk Utilityâ€‰â€”â€‰a very important appâ€‰â€”â€‰has an icon thatâ€™s just an Apple logo (inside the bolt thatâ€™s inside the wrench thatâ€™s inside the squircle). Not a hard disk, not an external drive, not an SD card. Just an Apple logo. If I just showed you this icon without telling you which app it represented, how in the world could you guess what it is? Even if you know the â€œApple utility app iconâ€ motif of the big dumb wrench and bolt, the best you could guess is â€œa utility app for something Apple-relatedâ€ which, for an Apple computer, could be anything.

  • Expansion Slot Utilityâ€‰â€”â€‰This app only runs on Mac Pros because Mac Pros are the only Macs with expansion slots. So the old icon naturally shows a Mac Pro. The new icon shows ... three rectangular empty sockets?

  • AppleScript Utilityâ€‰â€”â€‰A fine concept for this icon (within the confines of the terrible wrench-and-bolt utility icon concept). Everyone who knows AppleScript knows the scroll that represents AppleScript scripts. So just put the iconic AppleScript scroll in the bolt in the wrench in the squircle. But here, the placement of the scroll is botchedâ€‰â€”â€‰itâ€™s rotated a few degrees counterclockwise. It makes the scroll look like itâ€™s falling over. Hereâ€™s how the scroll is canonically oriented, via the glyphs in SF Symbols:

    and via the default icon for a script application (with a line added showing the center):

    But hereâ€™s a close-up of the Tahoe AppleScript Utility icon, with a center line added:

    Itâ€™s wrong.

These are not the work of carpenters who care about the backs of the cabinets theyâ€™re building. These icons are so bad, they look like the work of untrained â€œHow hard can it be?â€ dilettante carpenters who only last a few days on the job before sawing off one of their own fingers. The whole collection looks like the work from someone with no artistic ability nor an eye for detail. From Apple, of all companies.

Is it a big deal in the grand scheme of things that the icons for these seldom-used utility apps have gone to shit? No. But consider the proverbial canary in a coal mine. The problem isnâ€™t that one little bird has died. The problem is that the bird might be dead because the whole mine is filling with deadly carbon monoxide or highly flammable methane gas. The icons in /Applications/Utilities/ in MacOS 26 Tahoe represent a folder full of dead canaries.

entry.content:
Sara Fischer, Axios:

MSNBC, the progressive cable network owned by NBCUniversal, is rebranding to MS NOW, an acronym that stands for My Source for News, Opinion and the World.

The rebrand is part of a wider effort by NBCU to create a distinction between the cable networks it plans to spin out and the remaining NBCU parent company. As part of the rebrand, select cable networks that will be spun out into Versant, including CNBC, Golf Channel, GolfNow, MSNBC and SportsEngine, will all drop the iconic peacock logo that has for decades served as NBCUâ€™s logo.

Thereâ€™s a lot to unpack here. First, â€œVersantâ€ itself is a pretty bad name (feels so vagueâ€‰â€”â€‰seems like the name of a fake company in a movie or TV show) so itâ€™s no surprise that the same nitwits are botching Versantâ€™s rebranded properties. But given that NBCUniversal is apparently forcing MSNBC to take the â€œNBCâ€ out of its name, â€œMSNOWâ€ isnâ€™t a bad new name. But itâ€™s not a good new name either. And theyâ€™re apparently using a space: â€œMS NOWâ€, yet also seem confused (or havenâ€™t even decided yet) whether itâ€™s supposed to be pronounced letter-by-letter (em ess en oh dubya) or as two letters and a word (em ess now). Saying the â€œNOWâ€ as the word now makes sense for a 24/7 channel, but if itâ€™s a word, the whole name should be styled â€œMS Nowâ€. (Fox News styles their name as â€œFOX Newsâ€ in some places, but never pretends the f-o-x is an acronym.)

The â€œMy Source News Opinion Worldâ€ backronym is so dumb it boggles the mind. I genuinely wonder if someone had ChatGPT do that. You can have a series of letters as a nameâ€‰â€”â€‰especially as a TV channelâ€‰â€”â€‰without those letters really standing for anything. CNN is technically an acronym for â€œCable News Networkâ€ but theyâ€™ve effectively just been â€œCNNâ€ for decades now. The name â€œMSNBCâ€ came from the fact that, at launch in the 1990s, it debuted as a collaboration between Microsoftâ€™s MSN and NBC News. But Microsoft hasnâ€™t been involved with the cable channel for 20 yearsâ€‰â€”â€‰the â€œMSâ€ in â€œMSNBCâ€ hasnâ€™t stood for anything since 2005. (In fact, MSN itself is another good example. It originally stood for â€œMicrosoft Networkâ€, even though Microsoft has never styled their name with a camel-cased S.1 But itâ€™s really just â€œMSNâ€ now.)2

Tom Gara, writing on Threads:

The only real fuck up with the MSNBC rebrand is that they made up a dumb sounding fake acronym. Itâ€™s completely unnecessary! Just say â€œweâ€™re changing our name to MS NOW to reflect the urgency of the moment.â€ Nobody has ever thought about what the old acronym stood for and nobody needed a new fake one.

There is another fuck up, though: the logo is atrocious. What is that flag? It looks like the Austrian flag (ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡¹), not Americaâ€™s. But are we sure it even is a flag? Maybe itâ€™s a paper receipt and the red stripes are those marks when itâ€™s time to replace the roll? Jonathan Hoefler, on Threads:

My personal benchmark for a logo is that it shouldnâ€™t look like a pension fund.

The oddest part about the whole situation is that CNBC is being spun out into Versant, too, but while theyâ€™re losing the NBC peacock logo, theyâ€™re just keeping their name, unchanged. From CNBCâ€™s own coverage of MSNBCâ€™s rebranding:

While MSNBC and NBC News will have duplications in coverage, CNBCâ€™s news organization is already separate enough from NBC News that executives decided it didnâ€™t need a name change. Also, technically, the â€œNBCâ€ in â€œCNBCâ€ never stemmed from National Broadcasting Co. Rather, CNBC stands for â€œConsumer News and Business Channel.â€

Lastly, shoutout to M.G. Siegler for coining the term peacockblocked to describe MSNBCâ€™s branding plight.

But thatâ€™s not camel-case, and that hyphenated spelling is as much a footnote to Microsoftâ€™s brand history as the woodcut Isaac-Newton-under-a-tree logo is to Apple. Microsoftâ€™s logo from that era was very disco-â€™70s and kind of coolâ€‰â€”â€‰but while â€œMicroâ€ and â€œSoftâ€ were broken across two lines, thereâ€™s no hyphen in the logotype. ↩︎ï¸
